view

Class Projector

  • java.lang.Object
    • view.Projector
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class Projector
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    The Projector class simply takes an image, and projects it in either full screen mode, or in a JPanel for a given FPS value.      This class sets up the nitty gritty details for a refreshing frame in use for a game or other simulation. Here's a quick example for how to use Projector: 
     
  public class yourClass implements Pinterface
  {
        private Projector ip;
        private BufferedImage bi;
        private JPanel jp;
  
        public yourClass()
        {
                bi = new BufferedImage(400, 400, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB);
                ip = new GProjector(10f, bi, "Test", this);
                jp = ip.init(new Dimension(400, 400));
                //or just ip.init() for full screen.
        }
  
        public void iUpdate()
        {
        //Code that updates bi, goes here.
                }
        }
    Since:
    1.6 Bug fix to the way thread was created., 1.5 Several small convenience fixes have been made.
    Version:
    1.7 FSEM implemented for init() method.
    Author:
    Brian Nakayama

    • Constructor Detail

      • Projector

        public Projector(float fFps,
         java.awt.image.BufferedImage ISlide,
         java.lang.String sTitle,
         Pinterface iI)
        Creates the GProjector Object
        Parameters:
        fFps - A float representing the desired Frames per second.
        ISlide - The Image, or "slide", to be projected.
        sTitle - A String representing the title of the projection(FSM only)
        iI - The GFeed object that'll receive updates.

    • Method Detail

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        Simply returns if iProjector is running.
        Returns:
        A boolean defining the running status.

      • setInterface

        public void setInterface(Pinterface iI)
        Say that you wanted to switch updates between two different interfaces, one should use this to set a new one.
        Parameters:
        iI - The new interface to receive updates

      • setFPS

        public void setFPS(float fFps)
        Sets the Frames per Second float variable.
        Parameters:
        fFps - The new FPS rate

      • setSlide

        public void setSlide(java.awt.image.BufferedImage ISlide)
        Changes the Image/Slide pointer of the projection. I only recommend this if you need the original Image replaced, otherwise just update the original Image.
        Parameters:
        ISlide - The new Image, or Slide, pointer

      • isFS

        public boolean isFS()
        Returns if the projection is full screen or not.
        Returns:
        True if it is full screen

      • init

        public javax.swing.JPanel init(javax.swing.JFrame jf)
        Attempts to initiate a Full Screen Exclusive Mode(FSEM) Projection. Pass in the frame that will be fit to the screen. If FSEM is not available, then this will initiate a Full Screen Mode (FSM) that stretches the screen to fir using software.
        Parameters:
        jf - Just for reference.
        Returns:
        a created JPanel, again for reference.

      • init

        public javax.swing.JPanel init(int width,
                      int height)
        Initiates a projection on a JPanel of a certain size.
        Parameters:
        width - The width of the panel.
        height - The height of the panel.
        Returns:
        Returns the JPanel that will receive the Projections.

      • resume

        public void resume()
        Resumes the Projection thread if stopped.
